subject: RE: Test diagnostics (was Re: [junit] Help plz...)
msgSnippet: We also log for informal audit trail purposes. This allows us to assist our internal customers in problem determination. ... Simon P. Chappell
messageBody:
We also log for informal audit trail purposes. This allows us to assist our internal customers in problem determination.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
Simon P. Chappell simon.chappell@...
Java Programming Specialist www.landsend.com
Lands' End, Inc. (608) 935-4526

"Never give in - never, never, never, never, in nothing great or
small, large or petty, never give in except to convictions of
honor and good sense." - Sir Winston Churchill


>-----Original Message-----
>From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
>Sent: Thursday, September 18, 2003 5:30 PM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: Re: Test diagnostics (was Re: [junit] Help plz...)
>
>
>Malcolm Sparks wrote:
>
>> Good stuff. I accept all the good points made about using
>assertions in
>> unit tests. But the point I was making about logging was echoing this
>> sentiment:
>>
>> "Logging equips the developer with detailed context for application
>> failures. On the other hand, testing provides quality assurance and
>> confidence in the application. Logging and testing should not be
>> confused. They are complementary. When logging is wisely used, it can
>> prove to be an essential tool."
>> http://jakarta.apache.org/log4j/docs/index.html
>
>Yep. The problem is when one uses logging as a substitute for testing,
>which is still very, very common.
>
>In my opinion, one logs to help provide the context for complex
>troubleshooting. For anything simpler, one tests.
>
>Reasonable?
>--
>J. B. Rainsberger,
>Diaspar Software Services
>http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
>Let's write software that people understand
>
